properties.media:imagetext:
PERSONAL
December 30, 1937
Mr. Harold M. Bixby
Pan American Airways Co.
Manila, Philippine Islands
Dear Harold:
I was much interested in your personal letter of December 17
commenting upon recent developments in the war in China.
You and I are
seeing
this great drama from such widely divergent angles and interpret-
ing it from such different sources of infor atior that it is very inter-
esting to exchange views, not with the idea that either of us can really
claim to know anything but simply to compare notes, which must undoubtedly
give both of us some advantage in shaping our necessarily varying opin-
ionsâ€¢
I should like to comment seriatum ou some of your points as
follows:
1.
The fact that there was unanimity among the Chinese
political and military leaders with regard to the question of coming to
grips with Japan does not, I fear, mean that such unanimity can neces-
sarily continue unbroken during any long protracted struggle.
Chinese
history is not encouraging in this regard and you know yourself how un-
reliable sone of these people are in the face of discouragement and op-
portunities to pull out to their own advantage.
have no means of knowing, how much of any
treak there not ken in the
political and military united front of China, but I think you are assum-
ing a good deal when you assume that it is still unbroken.
It may not
crumble as fast as some people expect but I do think it will have a ten-
dency that way.
2.
You say
the war to date has gone pretty
much as
Chinese anticipated.
the
That is undoubtedly true so far as the map of mili-
tary operations shows the course of hostilities, but I doubt if the Chin-
ese ever anticipated the terrific debacle that they suffered at Nanking
and the very heavy loss of life and supplies (munitions, etc.) which they
have experienced.
that similar conditions would have On Occidentals.
You are probably right
in saying that they will take much more without cracking, because they
are used to adverse conditions.
Nevertheless, there must be a limit to
what even the Chinese coolie can endure, and it would seem that during the
month of Decenber they just about reached the breaking point.
